title: 104_hr1184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995". It addresses the treatment of certain charges. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 address third party fees, taxes on security instruments, and preparation of loan documents. The finance charge excludes fees imposed by third parties not required by the creditor. Taxes on security instruments are included if payment is necessary for recording. The Truth in Lending Act Amendments of 1995 address third party fees, taxes on security instruments, and preparation of loan documents. Section 106(e)(2) is amended to include fees for preparing loan-related documents and settlement. Section 106(e)(5) is amended to include fees related to pest infestations, inspections, and hazards. SEC. 3. EXEMPTIONS FROM RESCISSION. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to include exemptions for certain refinancings secured by a first lien. Also makes a technical and conforming amendment related to refinancing or consolidation transactions. SEC. 4. TOLERANCES; BASIS OF DISCLOSURES. (a) Tolerances for Accuracy.--Section 106 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a new subsection regarding the accuracy of disclosures in credit transactions secured by real property. The disclosed finance charge must not vary by more than half of the numerical tolerance for the annual percentage rate.
(b) Basis of Disclosure for Per Diem Interest.--Section 121(c) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include provisions for disclosing per diem interest accurately in consumer transactions. "In consumer credit transactions, accurate disclosure of per diem interest is required based on information known to the creditor at the time of preparing the transaction documents." SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON LIABILITY. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to include certain limitations on liability. Limitations on liability for disclosures of fees and charges other than finance charges for transactions before 1995. Creditors are not liable for certain taxes, fees, and delivery charges disclosed to consumers. Exceptions apply. Exceptions to the limitations on liability for disclosures of fees and charges before 1995 include individual actions or counterclaims filed before October 1, 1994, and class actions with certified classes before the same date alleging improper disclosure of charges. Exemptions from liability for finance charge disclosures within tolerance limits include individual plaintiffs in class actions filed before October 1, 1994, and consumer credit transactions with timely rescission notices sent before the same date. No creditor or assignee shall be liable for inaccurate finance charge disclosures if the disclosed amount is within tolerance limits or exceeds the required disclosure amount. Exceptions include individual actions filed before October 1, 1994. Exceptions to liability for inaccurate finance charge disclosures include individual actions filed before October 1, 1994, class actions with certified classes before the same date, named individual plaintiffs in class actions filed before October 1, 1994, and consumer credit transactions with timely notice of rescission sent to the creditor before October 1, 1994. SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY. The amendments made by this Act apply to all consumer credit transactions after the enactment date, except for rescission rights asserted before January 1, 1995. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON RESCISSION PERIOD. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON RESCISSION PERIOD. Amends the Truth in Lending Act to set a 3-year limit for consumers to assert rescission rights after a transaction, superseding any inconsistent state laws. SEC. 8. CALCULATION OF ACTUAL DAMAGES. Amends section 130(a) of the Truth in Lending Act to define actual damages as the difference between finance charges paid and what would have been paid under better credit terms available from another creditor. SEC. 9. ASSIGNEE LIABILITY. Section 131(a) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to hold assignees liable for apparent violations on the face of transaction documents. Civil actions against a creditor for violations can be maintained against an assignee only if the violation is evident on the disclosure statement and the assignment was voluntary. The Truth in Lending Act now holds assignees accountable for apparent violations on disclosure statements. A servicer of a consumer obligation is not considered an assignee unless they are the owner of the obligation. The Truth in Lending Act now holds assignees responsible for disclosure violations. A servicer of a consumer obligation is not deemed the owner unless they own the obligation, not just for administrative convenience.
